barker_notes.barker_summary: Editorial by Austin in Texas Gazette, July 8, 1830. Calming popular apprehension over the law of April 6, 1830.
barker_notes.barker_footnotes: Issue of July 3, 1830. It is followed by a translation of Teran's letter to Austin June 14, 1830, quoting letter to Piedras of same date giving interpretation of the law of April 6, 1830. This is followed by translation of the law of April 6.

*div1 type="summary"* *p*Editorial by Austin in Texas Gazette, July 8, 1830. Calming popular apprehension over the law of April 6, 1830.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p*We this day publish a translation of the law passed by the National Congress, on the *date_mentioned n="04-06-1830">6th of April last*/date_mentioned*, and also, the official letter of his *person_mentioned*Excellency General Manuel de Mier y Teran,*/person_mentioned* to the *person_mentioned*Empresario of this colony*/person_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*By an attentive perusal of the law it will be seen, that the privileges granted in it relative to the coasting trade, and to the introduc- tion of provisions and lumber free of duty into the *location_mentioned*ports of Galveston and Matagorda */location_mentioned*are of the highest importance to the prosperity of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, and must tend most efficiently to promote its rapid advancement.*/p*
*p*The encouragement offered for the establishment of *location_mentioned*manufactories*/location_mentioned* is also important, and there cannot be a doubt that many enterprising *person_mentioned*capitalists */person_mentioned*will turn their attention to that branch of industry. Perhaps no *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*combines more real advantages than are presented in *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*for the establishment of cotton and woolen *location_mentioned*factories*/location_mentioned*. The raw material of the best quality can be raised in the greatest abundance, and cheaper than in any other part of *location_mentioned*North America.*/location_mentioned* Our soil yields the most luxuriant growth of cotton of the best quality. Our natural *location_mentioned*pasturage */location_mentioned*for sheep, in the *location_mentioned*undulating and hilly sections in the northern parts of Texas,*/location_mentioned* are surpassed by none in any *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*; and countless thousands of them may be raised, with no other expense than a few shepherds. Provisions may be easily produced. Good situations for machinery, with water, steam, or ox power are numerous. Our *location_mentioned*harbors */location_mentioned*are sufficient for all the purposes of commerce. Our communications with the *location_mentioned*Mexican ports*/location_mentioned* are open and unembarrassed. The *location_mentioned*markets*/location_mentioned*, in those *location_mentioned*ports*/location_mentioned*, are the best in the *location_mentioned*world*/location_mentioned*, for the sale of cotton or other woolen goods, such as might be manufactured in *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*. In short, all that nature and a liberal and munificent government can do has been done, and nothing is now wanting but capital, enterprise and industry.*/p*
*p*The 10th. article of the law clearly secures the rights of the *person_mentioned*colonists */person_mentioned*who are already settled. It also guarantees the rights of all the *person_mentioned*emigrants */person_mentioned*who are comprehended in the contracts of *person_mentioned*empresarios */person_mentioned*whose*location_mentioned* colonies are established*/location_mentioned*, and permits the full completion of such contracts, to the full number contracted for. So that emigration to the *location_mentioned*colony */location_mentioned*is not stopped as was erroneously rumored. The *person_mentioned*settlers */person_mentioned*who are not comprehended in any *location_mentioned*colony*/location_mentioned*, may also be provided for, as will be seen by reference to the powers granted to the General Government [Commandant] in the 3rd article.*/p*
*p*The official letter of his*person_mentioned* Excellency General Teran,*/person_mentioned* the *person_mentioned*commissioner of the General Government*/person_mentioned*, under the 3rd article, is very clear and explicit, as to the interpretation of the law, and as to the just and liberal views of the General Government, under whose instructions he is acting.*/p*
*p*The name of this distinguished *person_mentioned*patriot */person_mentioned*and scientific *person_mentioned*general */person_mentioned*is closely connected with some of the most interesting events in *person_mentioned*Mexican*/person_mentioned* history. A *person_mentioned*soldier */person_mentioned*under the banner of freedom from the first epoch of the revolution, he has uniformly been a firm defender of the rights of his *location_mentioned*countrymen*/location_mentioned*. As a *person_mentioned*legislator in the first constituent congress*/person_mentioned*, his voice was raised in opposition to despotism and in favor of a free, liberal and constitutional government. As *person_mentioned*secretary of war*/person_mentioned* he established system and organization in the army after the convulsions of the *person_mentioned*Emperor*/person_mentioned*'s short reign. At *location_mentioned*Tampico */location_mentioned*the *person_mentioned*invaders */person_mentioned*of his *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*sank before his military genius, and received from his humanity that protection and succor which their prowess could not secure to them. As *person_mentioned*commandant general of the eastern military department and commissioner of the General Government for regulating the colonies of Texas*/person_mentioned* and establishing new ones, he will provide for the defense and permanent security of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*from the *person_mentioned*Indians*/person_mentioned*, and lay a foundation for such additional colonial *location_mentioned*establishments */location_mentioned*and *location_mentioned*maritime towns*/location_mentioned* and fortifications as may be necessary to advance its prosperity.*/p*
*p*The section of *location_mentioned*country east of this colony*/location_mentioned* and particularity the *location_mentioned*Nacogdoches */location_mentioned*and *location_mentioned*Ais district*/location_mentioned*s, demand the prompt attention of government. The land affairs of those sections require adjustment, and a totally different organization of the local government is much needed. Instead of having the whole civil and judicial power of the *person_mentioned*local government*/person_mentioned* vested in *person_mentioned*alcaldes */person_mentioned*elected annually, it would be better to have a separate *location_mentioned*partido */location_mentioned*laid off with a *person_mentioned*chief of partido*/person_mentioned*, and in addition to the *person_mentioned*alcaldes */person_mentioned*there ought to be a *person_mentioned*juez de letras, or judge learned in the law*/person_mentioned*, appointed in the manner prescribed in the constitution, with a salary to insure a man of talents and qualifications. It is sufficient to merely know how the *person_mentioned*local government*/person_mentioned* of that section of *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*is and always has been organized to understand the causes of all the little *location_mentioned*local */location_mentioned*difficulties which have arisen there. It cannot be supposed that an *person_mentioned*alcalde */person_mentioned*annually changed and elected by popular vote from the mass of a people speaking a variety of languages and who are themselves in general ignorant of the laws should be capable of discharging so important and responsible a position as that of a *person_mentioned*judge*/person_mentioned*, whose jurisdiction embraces the investigation of all matters of controversy and all criminal cases without limit. Under three hundred dollars his jurisdiction is final, over that sum there is the right of appeal to the *location_mentioned*supreme court at Saltillo*/location_mentioned*, six hundred miles distant. The *person_mentioned*alcaldes*/person_mentioned*, however, cannot give final judgement in any important civil case and in no capital criminal case, without first consulting the *person_mentioned*assesor general*/person_mentioned*, or *person_mentioned*attorney general */person_mentioned*who lives at *location_mentioned*Saltillo*/location_mentioned*. It is very evident that such a system cannot secure to the people, nor to the government the benefits which organization and regular administration of the laws are designed to produce. The objections to the present *person_mentioned*alcalde */person_mentioned*system will apply more or less to every part of the state, and are very evident. They are severely felt here as well as elsewhere, for although the public tranquility has never been interrupted in this *location_mentioned*colony */location_mentioned*from its first establishment up to the present time, yet great individual inconvenience is daily experienced from this mode of administration of the laws.*/p*
*/div1*
